‚ÄúUsually when someone talks about a panic attack or an episode  they‚Äôre 100% sure that something is not right with their emotions. For me  it was small things. I wasn't focused. I couldn't concentrate.

I felt guilt both professionally and personally. And then I felt guilty for feeling guilty because at the same time  I had a roof above my head. I had food and my health. It became a snowball effect.

Finally  I got up the courage to talk to my manager  and he was very supportive  and told me that Microsoft offered flexibility to where I was able to work during the pandemic. When I went back to Brazil  I spent the time with my family‚Äîme  my mom  my brother  and our dog. I felt very fortunate to be there for my mom to support her during this time. I realized that what I needed was that time with them‚Äîthings like gathering around the table over coffee to talk. Staying at home with my family was medicine for the loneliness I‚Äôd been feeling.

After that  something just clicked. I started to take action. I took a class I‚Äôd always wanted to take  and I shared my story on LinkedIn.

We all have blockers sometimes to talk about these kinds of things at work  but our leaders encouraged me to open up.
